description: Borrowed from Latin decussātus from decussāre (“to divide crosswise, arrange crosswise or mark with a cross”), from decussis (“a 10 asses coin”), from decem (“ten”) + as (“a Roman coin”). Based on the cross marking on the decussis coin.

adjectives.description: decussate (comparative more decussate, superlative most decussate)

entries.meaning: Crossed; intersected; resembling a letter X.
(zoology) Having anatomical structures or markings crossing each other, typically in an X shape or at right angles.
(botany) Having opposite leaves arranged alternately at right angles.
(rhetoric) Consisting of two rising and two falling clauses, placed in alternate opposition to each other.

verbs.description: decussate (third-person singular simple present decussates, present participle decussating, simple past and past participle decussated)

entries.meaning: To form an X or to cross or intersect.
